Award.AwardTitle: Variational Methods for the Analysis of Unsupervised Learning Algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Unsupervised learning can be described as the task of finding structure from unlabeled observations. This is a fundamental task in scientific fields like biology, material science, economics, and astronomy, where in a typical scenario researchers possess a large number of unlabeled data, but only a few (or none) expert labeled data points, as these are typically very expensive to obtain. This project focuses on the mathematical analysis of data science algorithms for unsupervised learning. Broadly speaking, the aim of the investigation is to contribute to the development of mathematical foundations for data science and artificial intelligence by providing rigorous mathematical theory supporting methodologies used in practice, as well as by proposing principled novel ones. The investigator will not only study individual algorithms, but find common structure between them and highlight their otherwise unclear unity.

Among the many methodologies for unsupervised learning found in the literature, graph-based methods occupy a prominent role, and they will be the focus of this investigation. These are algorithms that rely on having access to similarity graphs, which endow data sets with a geometric structure. Different graphs capture different features of a given data set and hence are useful for different tasks. The project will focus on the following concrete directions: 1) the proposal and analysis of new algorithms for unsupervised learning inspired by variational methods for evolution on metric spaces and in particular on the space of probability measures over discrete and semi-discrete structures. In this direction the main goal is to introduce a mathematical formalism for the design of new learning methodologies, and to use this formalism in order to build connections between seemingly unrelated statistical procedures like those inspired by mode-seeking techniques as the ones based on spectral methods. Some of the applications in mind go beyond unsupervised learning, and also include the systematic testing of deep neural network architectures. The second direction concerns the study of statistical properties of graph-based unsupervised learning algorithms in settings where graphs capturing the geometry of a data set are very sparse (below standard connectivity), or where data generating distributions are degenerate and violate standard geometric assumptions found in the literature. In this direction, the goal is to identify the limits of sparsity that allow for meaningful learning, as well as to develop quantitative statistical error analysis for solutions to non-convex optimization problems on graphs built on data sets, for graphs that are connected to a ground truth geometric model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the widespread use of machine learning and data analysis methodologies across various application domains in recent years, there has been an increased interest in the scientific community to unveil the mathematical principles underlying these methods. In this project, the PI and his collaborators explored a range of methodologies in data science and machine learning with a common theme: a close connection to optimization problems over geometric objects and/or association with partial differential equations, which traditionally are used to describe physical phenomena like heat propagation. The link between data analysis algorithms, on the one hand, and equations and optimization problems typically found in mathematical analysis or geometry, on the other, is an important theme across the project. This interaction between seemingly unrelated topics has also inspired the proposal of new algorithms in data science with theoretical guarantees.

In more concrete terms, the PI and his collaborators established new theoretical foundations for graph-based clustering in mathematical settings that better resemble real-life application scenarios than previous theoretical studies; clustering, in this context, refers to identifying relevant group structures in datasets. They also provided new theoretical insights for unsupervised learning methodologies such as diffusion maps, and they proposed new forms of interpolation between density-driven and geometry-based unsupervised learning algorithms, two well-known general perspectives in the machine learning literature for unsupervised learning (including clustering), providing in this way further mathematical insights into traditionally unrelated methodologies.

As part of the project, the PI and collaborators used the opportunity to present the theoretical foundations of graph-based semi-supervised learning in an expository article. Semi-supervised learning, closely related to unsupervised learning, involves having additional "label" information for some data points within a larger collection of data. The tools discussed in that manuscript heavily rely on variational techniques, specifically on the variational formulation of posterior updates in Bayesian statistics.

The project also delved into studying path distances and curvature in datasets and establishing their close relation to analogous notions on more standard geometric objects like spheres or flat surfaces. The implications of these analytical results on unsupervised and supervised learning methodologies were discussed by the PI and collaborators, and in particular, they support the use of data-driven “curvature” constraints in learning representations for data.

The PI and collaborators also proposed new methods for finding suitable "neural architectures" in supervised learning problems, aiming to identify the best tool within a class of existing tools to solve a given learning problem.

Furthermore, the project played a crucial role in paving the way for new and profound explorations of the theoretical foundations of adversarial machine learning in supervised classification settings. Adversarial machine learning, an area of modern machine learning, focuses on studying and developing methods to construct learning models that are robust to adversarial perturbations of data. These problems are particularly relevant in various safety-critical applications, aligning with the overarching goal of making data analysis and machine algorithms safe, fair, and robust.

In addition to the aforementioned research outcomes, the project was essential in developing several topic courses for graduate students at the PI’s institution. These courses contributed to the formation of a new generation of researchers at the interface between mathematics, statistics, and machine learning. Three new PhD students joined the PI in the research endeavors prompted by this project, along with multiple Master’s students who participated in weekly reading groups and extracurricular discussion sessions on the role that mathematics can play in the development of data science.
